sidebyside.p: An important characteristics of fluids is that there is no significant reaction force from the fluid when you apply a force horizontal to the free surface of the fluid. The fluid simply flows under such a force.

On the other hand, if you push on a fluid such that the fluid cannot flow and the force results in change in volume, thus resulting in a volumetric strain, then a stress develops inside the fluid. The stress in fluid is called pressure. Suppose F_\text{reaction} is reaction force developed inside the fluid as a result of an external force F_\tet{ext}. Since force acts on area A_\perp. Then, pressure inside the dluid will be
p = \dfrac{F_\text{reaction}}{A_\perp}.

subsection.title: Units of Pressure
subsection.p:
The dimension of pressure is
[p] = [M][L]^{-1}[T]^{-2},
and therefore the unit in SI system is
\text{kg/m.s}^2\text{ called Pascal (Pa)},
in honor of the French mathematician and physicist Blaise Pascal (1623-1662).

Actually, other units of pressure are in more common use in physics, engineering, and other sciences. For instance, the ambient pressure due to the atmosphere is called one atmosphere (atm) which is
1\text{ atm} \approx 1.013\times10^5\text{ Pa}.

sidebyside.p:
The pressure at the bottom of a 760-mm high column of mercury at 0^{\circ}\text{ C} in a container where the top part is evacuated is equal to the atmospheric pressure. Thus, 760-mmHg is also used in place of 1 atmospheric pressure.
1\text{ atm} = 760\text{ mmHg}.

subsection.p:
In vacuum physics labs, one often uses another unit called Torr, named after the Italian inventor Evangelista Torricelli (1608-1647), who invented the mercury manometer for measuring pressure. One Torr is equal to a pressure of 1\text{ mmHg}. Low pressures in atmospheric physics and high vacuum physics are often expressed in yet another unit called millibar or mbar, which is equal to 100 Pa, with a bar being 10^5\text{ Pa}. The multitude of units for pressure is certainly very confusing to students. Perhaps, when doing problems, you should stick to \text{Pa}.
1\text{ Torr} = 1\text{ mmHg}, 1\text{ bar} = 10^5\text{ Pa}, 1\text{ mbar} = 100\text{ Pa}.
Not to be left out is the pounds per square inch ( \text{psi} ) will be the English unit of pressure - this is used, for instance in tire pressure in USA:
1\text{ psi} = 7.015\times10^3\text{ Pa} = \dfrac{1}{14.7}\text{ atm}.

subsection.title: Range of Pressure
subsection.p: displays pressure under various conditions in nature.

statement.p: In a zero gravity and vacuum environment, nitrogen gas is kept at a pressure of 50,000\text{ Pa} in a rigid cylinder with a movable piston. The area of the piston is 20\text{ cm}^2. What force must be applied on the piston to keep the gas from expanding?

hint.p: Balance the forces on the piston.

solution.p:
Let F be the magnitude of the force required to act normally to the piston. Then, this force must balance the force by the pressure of the gas.
F = pA.
Now, before we put in the numerical values, we need to convert area in \text{m}^2.
A = 20\text{ cm}^2 = 20\times 10^{-4}\text{ m}^2,
where note that we need a factor of (1/100)^2. Therefore, we have
F = 50,000 \times 20\times 10^{-4} = 100\text{ N}.

exercise.title: Pressure of Same Magnitude Force Acting on a Pin Versus on a Nail

statement.p: Compare the pressures by a 1\text{ N} force on a pin and a nail. The tip of the pin has a diameter of 10\ \mu\text{m} and the nail 100\ \mu\text{m}.

solution.p:
First we work out the areas in \text{m}^2.
A_\text{pin} \amp = \dfrac{\pi}{4}d^2 = \dfrac{\pi}{4}\times 10^{-10}\text{ m}^2, A_\text{nail} \amp = \dfrac{\pi}{4}d^2 = \dfrac{\pi}{4}\times 10^{-8}\text{ m}^2,

Dividing the force by the area will give pressure in each case.
p_\text{pin} \amp = 1.27\times 10^{10}\text{ Pa}, p_\text{nail} \amp = 1.27\times 10^{8}\text{ Pa}.

statement.p: In a low pressure laboratory, partial vacuum of 1.0 \times 10^{-6}\text{ Torr} is achieved. (a) What is the corresponding reading in millibar? (b) How much is that in psi? (c) How much is that in Pa?

hint.p: Look up the unit conversion factors.

solution.p: Using the conversion factors gives the results.

exercise.title: Opening a Door on a Windy Day - Handling Pressure Difference

statement.p: On a windy day, the air pressure outside a 90 cm x 200 cm door is 943 mbar, while the air pressure inside the building is 1013 mbar. How much force you must apply at the handle of the door to open it if the door is hinged on the long side?

hint.p: (1) Place the force by pressures at the center. (2) Balance the torque by your force.

solution.p:
The force by outside air and inside air could both be placed at the center of th door. Say, we apply a force F at the handle. Then, the torque balancing will give us the following equation.
F w = \left[ (p_\text{in} - p_\text{out})wh \right]\, \dfrac{w}{2}.
Solving for F we get
F = \dfrac{1}{2} (p_\text{in} - p_\text{out})wh.
Putting in the numerical values requires us to convert \text{mbar} to \text{Pa}.
\dfrac{1}{2} \times (1013 - 943)\times \times 10^{2} \times 0.9\times 2.0 = 630\text{ N}.
